answers.body_markdown:
I thing flutter WebView in which Razorpay is running doesn't have access to the getDeviceDetails function. This could be due to a number of reasons:

**The function is not defined:** Ensure that the getDeviceDetails function is properly defined in your code.

**The function is not in scope:** If the function is defined, make sure it's in the correct scope. JavaScript functions can only be called from within the scope they're defined in.

**The WebView settings**: The settings for the WebView might be preventing the function from being called. You might need to enable JavaScript or adjust other settings.

**The Razorpay library:** There might be an issue with the version of the Razorpay library you're using. Try updating to the latest version or down grade some version.

answers.body:
You need to send a request to Razorpay to generate an Order ID. like this:

curl -u <YOUR_KEY_ID>:<YOUR_SECRET> \
-X POST https://api.razorpay.com/v1/orders \
-H "content-type: application/json" \
-d '{
  "amount": 50000,
  "currency": "INR",
  "receipt": "receipt#1",
  "payment_capture": 1
}'

I have created a distinct method to produce an Order ID within my application.

import 'dart:convert';
import 'package:http/http.dart' as http;

Future<String> generateOrderId(String key, String secret,int amount) async{
  var authn = 'Basic ' + base64Encode(utf8.encode('$key:$secret'));

  var headers = {
    'content-type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': authn,
  };

  var data = '{ "amount": $amount, "currency": "INR", "receipt": "receipt#R1", "payment_capture": 1 }'; // as per my experience the receipt doesn't play any role in helping you generate a certain pattern in your Order ID!!

  var res = await http.post('https://api.razorpay.com/v1/orders', headers: headers, body: data);
  if (res.statusCode != 200) throw Exception('http.post error: statusCode= ${res.statusCode}');
  print('ORDER ID response => ${res.body}');

  return json.decode(res.body)['id'].toString();
}

answers.title: Java: Unable to unzip a gzip compressed file?
answers.body:
"... What am I doing wrong? I have verified that file is in fact GZIP format and it's not corrupted. ..."

Return a byte array from readUsingFileInputStream, and use the String constructor to create a UTF-8 value.

/**
 * Read file content into a String
 */
private static byte[] readUsingFileInputStream(String fileName) throws IOException {
    try (FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(fileName)) {
        return fis.readAllBytes();
    }
}

/**
 * Unzip file content
 */
public static String unzip(final byte[] compressed) throws IOException {
    try (final GZIPInputStream gzipInput = new GZIPInputStream(new ByteArrayInputStream(compressed))) {
        return new String(gzipInput.readAllBytes(), StandardCharsets.UTF_8);
    }
}

Example

byte[] compressedData = readUsingFileInputStream("/path/to/my/compressed_file_json.gz");
System.out.println(unzip(compressedData));

answers.title: How can I fix my code to accept a basic number input the first time, not the second time?
answers.body:
The problem you are experiencing arises from the fact that when you're using methods like nextDouble(), you're actually consuming input. Each time you call this method, the scanner will read from the input source.

import java.util.Scanner;

public class CountDownByTwos {
   public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);

        System.out.println("Input a positive number and I will count down by 2");

        // Keep prompting the user until a valid input is provided
        double num = -1; // initialized to a negative number to ensure the loop runs at least once
        while (num < 0) {
            if (!in.hasNextDouble()) {
                String input = in.next();
                System.err.println(input + " is not a number, try again please");
            } else {
                num = in.nextDouble();
                if (num < 0) {
                    System.err.println("Please input a POSITIVE number.");
                    num = -1; // reset it to a negative value so the loop will continue
                }
            }
        }

        // for statement to count down
        for (double i = num; i >= 0; i = i - 2) {
            System.out.println(i);
        }
    }
}

answers.title: How can I fix my code to accept a basic number input the first time, not the second time?
answers.body:
You are getting two inputs because you are calling in.nextDouble() twice, once when checking if it is negative, and once when declaring the num variable.

This code worked for me: `

import java.util.Scanner;

public class CountDownByTwos {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);

        System.out.println("Input a positive number and I will count down by 2");

        //our number used for input
        double num = 0;

        boolean isNum = false;

        //getting input while their input is not a number
        while(!isNum) {
            //trying to get a double input, if not double it is caught
            try {
                //getting the input
                num = in.nextDouble();
                isNum = true;
            } catch (Exception e) {
                //if input was caught
                String input = in.nextLine();
                System.err.println(input + " is not a number, try again please");
                //going to the start of the loop again
                continue;
            }
            //if the try catch succeeded
            if(num < 0){
                //making isNum false so we start the loop again
                isNum = false;
                System.err.println("Please input a POSITIVE number next time");
            }
        }

        for (double i = num; i >= 0; i -= 2) {
            System.out.println(i);
        }
    }
}

`

answers.title: How can I fix my code to accept a basic number input the first time, not the second time?
answers.body:
The issue you're encountering is due to the way you structured your code. The hasNextDouble() and nextDouble() methods of the Scanner class should be used together to ensure proper input reading. In your current code, you're calling in.nextDouble() multiple times without re-prompting the user for input.

import java.util.Scanner;

public class CountDownByTwos {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);
        
        double num = 0; // Initialize num
        
        // Get a valid positive number from the user
        while (true) {
            System.out.println("Input a positive number and I will count down by 2");
            
            if (in.hasNextDouble()) {
                num = in.nextDouble();
                if (num >= 0) {
                    break; // Break the loop if a valid positive number is provided
                } else {
                    System.err.println("Please input a POSITIVE number");
                }
            } else {
                String input = in.next();
                System.err.println(input + " is not a number, try again please");
            }
        }
        
        // Use a for loop to count down by 2 until it reaches 0
        for (double i = num; i >= 0; i -= 2) {
            System.out.println(i);
        }
    }
}

In this code:

  1. We initialize num to 0 outside the loop to ensure it's defined before being used.

  2. We use a while loop to repeatedly prompt the user for input until a valid positive number is provided.

  3. Inside the loop, we use hasNextDouble() to check if the next input is a double. If it is, we then check if it's greater than or equal to 0. If both conditions are met, we break out of the loop. If not, we display an error message.

  4. If the input is not a valid double, we display an error message and continue the loop.

  5. Once a valid positive number is obtained, we use a for loop to count down by 2 until it reaches 0.

answers.title: how to compare the Java Byte[] array?
answers.body:
If you're trying to use the array as a generic HashMap key, that's not going to work. Consider creating a custom wrapper object that holds the array, and whose equals(...) and hashcode(...) method returns the results from the java.util.Arrays methods. For example...

import java.util.Arrays;

public class MyByteArray {
   private byte[] data;

   // ... constructors, getters methods, setter methods, etc...


   @Override
   public int hashCode() {
      return Arrays.hashCode(data);
   }

   @Override
   public boolean equals(Object obj) {
      if (this == obj)
         return true;
      if (obj == null)
         return false;
      if (getClass() != obj.getClass())
         return false;
      MyByteArray other = (MyByteArray) obj;
      if (!Arrays.equals(data, other.data))
         return false;
      return true;
   }


}

Objects of this wrapper class will work fine as a key for your HashMap<MyByteArray, OtherType> and will allow for clean use of equals(...) and hashCode(...) methods.

public static boolean equals(byte[] a, byte[] a2) {
        if (a == a2)
            return true;
        if (a == null || a2 == null)
            return false;

        int length = a.length;
        if (a2.length != length)
            return false;

        for (int i = 0; i < length; i++)
            if (a[i] != a2[i])
                return false;

        return true;

answers.title: how to compare the Java Byte[] array?
answers.body:
Arrays.equals is not enough for a comparator, you can not check the map contain the data. I copy the code from Arrays.equals, modified to build a Comparator.

class ByteArrays{
    public static <T> SortedMap<byte[], T> newByteArrayMap() {
        return new TreeMap<>(new ByteArrayComparator());
    }

    public static SortedSet<byte[]> newByteArraySet() {
        return new TreeSet<>(new ByteArrayComparator());
    }

    static class ByteArrayComparator implements Comparator<byte[]> {
        @Override
        public int compare(byte[] a, byte[] b) {
            if (a == b) {
                return 0;
            }
            if (a == null || b == null) {
                throw new NullPointerException();
            }

            int length = a.length;
            int cmp;
            if ((cmp = Integer.compare(length, b.length)) != 0) {
                return cmp;
            }

            for (int i = 0; i < length; i++) {
                if ((cmp = Byte.compare(a[i], b[i])) != 0) {
                    return cmp;
                }
            }

            return 0;
        }
    }
}

answers.title: Struggling with split text with number in between 1 to 45 using regex in java
answers.body:
Here is sample code that does what you want:

import java.util.regex.Pattern;

class Main{
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String s = "09 Software for use in assisted driving of railway vehicles; software for electronic railway driving assistance systems; hardware for electronic railway driving assistance systems; driver assistance systems for railway vehicles. 37 Installation and replacement services for railway vehicles, railway vehicles that incorporate driver assistance systems in the detection and avoidance of excessive speed, obstacles, vehicles and people; Software installation and replacement services for railway driving assistance systems and vehicle network coordination centers 42 Supervision services for driving. assistance; systems for railway vehicles; checking railway vehicles; checking railway vehicles that incorporate driver assistance systems";

        // split on numbers 
        Pattern p = Pattern.compile("\\s*(?:\\d+)\\s*");
        String[] arr = p.split(s);

        // capture the numbers seperately
        String[] numbers = p.matcher(s).results().map(m -> m.group().strip()).toArray(String[]::new);

        for (int i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) {
            System.out.printf("%s: \"%s\"\n", numbers[i-1], arr[i]);// first split is empty, so first string is at index 1

        }

    }
}

answers.body_markdown:
By combining subqueries and the string_agg function, you can get the desired results. However, you must modify your SQL query in a few specific ways. Here is an illustration of how to accomplish it:

    SELECT
        gr.id AS group_id,
        string_agg(d.name || '(' || COALESCE(CAST(sub.count AS text), '0') || ')', '; ') AS "Discipline Counts"
    FROM
        dm_group gr
    LEFT JOIN (
        SELECT
            g.id AS group_id,
            u.id AS user_id,
            d.name AS discipline_name
        FROM
            dm_user_to_group utg
        JOIN
            dm_group g ON utg.group_id = g.id
        JOIN
            dm_user u ON utg.user_id = u.id
        LEFT JOIN
            dm_group d ON u.id = d.id AND d.entity_type = 'Discipline'
        WHERE
            g.group_type = 'Math'
    ) AS sub ON gr.id = sub.group_id
    GROUP BY
        gr.id
    ORDER BY
        gr.id;

This should return a list of group_ids and the subjects they are linked with, together with the number of users for each subject related to the 'Math' group type. Change the table and column names to correspond to your actual database schema.

Hope it works :)
answers.title: PostgreSQL Using string_agg with count
answers.body:
By combining subqueries and the string_agg function, you can get the desired results. However, you must modify your SQL query in a few specific ways. Here is an illustration of how to accomplish it:

SELECT
    gr.id AS group_id,
    string_agg(d.name || '(' || COALESCE(CAST(sub.count AS text), '0') || ')', '; ') AS "Discipline Counts"
FROM
    dm_group gr
LEFT JOIN (
    SELECT
        g.id AS group_id,
        u.id AS user_id,
        d.name AS discipline_name
    FROM
        dm_user_to_group utg
    JOIN
        dm_group g ON utg.group_id = g.id
    JOIN
        dm_user u ON utg.user_id = u.id
    LEFT JOIN
        dm_group d ON u.id = d.id AND d.entity_type = 'Discipline'
    WHERE
        g.group_type = 'Math'
) AS sub ON gr.id = sub.group_id
GROUP BY
    gr.id
ORDER BY
    gr.id;

This should return a list of group_ids and the subjects they are linked with, together with the number of users for each subject related to the 'Math' group type. Change the table and column names to correspond to your actual database schema.

Hope it works :)

answers.body_markdown:
Here is my guess:

~~~pgsql
SELECT id, string_agg(dis_ct, '; ') AS "Discipline Counts"
FROM  (
   SELECT tr.id, d.name || '(' || count(DISTINCT d.id) || ')' AS dis_ct
   FROM   dm_group           tr
   LEFT   JOIN user_to_group ug ON ug.group_id = tr.id
   LEFT   JOIN dm_user       u  ON u.id = ug.user_id
   LEFT   JOIN dm_group      d  ON d.id = u.id
                               AND d.entity_type = 'Discipline'
   WHERE  tr.group_type = 'TRAINER'
   GROUP  BY tr.id, d.name
   ORDER  BY tr.id, d.name
   ) sub
GROUP  BY tr.id
ORDER  BY tr.id;
~~~

Aggregate counts in a subquery. Then aggregate the desired string format at the outer level.

If no matching row in `d` is found, the count would be 0. But concatenating that to `d.name` (which then is `null`, consequently) removes these noise counts anyway, so no `FILTER` needed.

   FROM   dm_group           tr
   LEFT   JOIN user_to_group ug ON ug.group_id = tr.id
   LEFT   JOIN dm_user       u  ON u.id = ug.user_id
   LEFT   JOIN dm_group      d  ON d.id = u.id
                               AND d.entity_type = 'Discipline'
   WHERE  tr.group_type = 'TRAINER'
   GROUP  BY tr.id, d.name
   ORDER  BY tr.id, d.name
   ) sub
GROUP  BY tr.id
ORDER  BY tr.id;

Aggregate counts in a subquery. Then aggregate the desired string format at the outer level.

If no matching row in d is found, the count would be 0. But concatenating that to d.name (which then is null, consequently) removes these noise counts anyway, so no FILTER needed.

I have to create a query to show **group_id** and the *list with the main user's subjects and number of people from this group per subjects*.

Hello, I agree that it's difficult to understand. Sorry for that.
There's some steps to make it easy to understand.
Here is used one table(**dm_group gr**) for **two** facts: 

1. To show to is discipline leader (gr.entity_type='Group' and gr.group_type='TRAINER'), so I can identify only teachers. 
In this case gr.name will be teacher's name.

2. But every user has at least one line in dm_group gr, which shows what is his the main subject/direction (gr.entity_type = 'Discipline'). In this case gr.name will be exactly the name of the main user's subject.

So, one user, as a teacher forms a group to what students can be assigned. And generally, every user has a main subject he is also assigned to. 
 Finally, I should identify all teacher's ids with the list of all their students subjects with number of user's.

1. So, first of all we identify **all the teachers** (select gr.id where group_type='TRAINER')
2. Next in **dm_user_to_group utg** we find all users assigned to each teacher(**select u.id where utg.id = gr.id**)
3. So the next step is *tricky*, knowing all user_ids for each teacher, I have to find all group ids for this users to find in dm_group their main subject(**where gr.entity_type = 'Discipline'**) and finally to get how much people have this or that subject as the main in each teacher's group.

Result should be like: group_id| subject(#);subject(#);..., where subject is the number of people from group and related to concrete subject.

I wrote smth like this:

*But it doesn't work as expected.. 

```
SELECT tr.id AS "Trainer ID",
       string_agg(info.name || '(' || info.number || ')',
                  '; ' order by info.name
           ) AS "Discipline Counts"
FROM (
         SELECT d.name, count(u.userid) as number
         FROM dm_group tr
                  LEFT JOIN
              dm_user_to_group utg ON tr.id = utg.group_id
                  LEFT JOIN
              dm_user u ON utg.user_id = u.userid
                  LEFT JOIN
              dm_group d ON u.userid = d.id AND d.entity_type = 'Discipline'
         group by d.name, u.userid) info
         full outer JOIN dm_group tr on tr.name = info.name
where tr.group_type = 'TRAINER'
GROUP BY tr.id
ORDER BY tr.id;
```

Tables used:

`dm_group`:

```
create table dm_group (
  entity_type  varchar(15) not null,
  id           bigserial primary key,
  description  text
  name         varchar(255),
  group_type   varchar(255)
);
```

`dm_user_to_group`:

```
create table dm_user_to_group (
  group_id bigint constraint fk_gr_to_u references dm_group,
  user_id  bigint constraint fk_us_to_gr references dm_user
);
```

comments.body_markdown: As a standard sanity-debugging step: print the content of `choice` before you start switching, and print it between some brackets, to see what's actually in it. And those brackets are important, because you want to see whether there are any special whitespace characters or not.

comments.body: @Mike'Pomax'Kamermans Thanks, I did it, and it didnt print out anything. Its a blank line. Im guessing the scanner didnt take the input, but why?

comments.body_markdown: `scanner.nextInt()` won't consume the new line which is in the buffer, so your next call to `String choice = scanner.nextLine();` will return an empty `String`.  Instead of calling `scanner.nextLine();` after it (which you seem to have identified as a symptom of the problem), call `scanner.nextLine();` before `String choice = scanner.nextLine();`
comments.body: scanner.nextInt() won't consume the new line which is in the buffer, so your next call to String choice = scanner.nextLine(); will return an empty String. Instead of calling scanner.nextLine(); after it (which you seem to have identified as a symptom of the problem), call scanner.nextLine(); before String choice = scanner.nextLine();

comments.body_markdown: @Prime I only understand it from an observational point of view, but when you time something into the console, the `Scanner` will consume all the text, including the new line character (which is injected when you press enter). `nextInt` will only remove the characters from the buffer which form a valid `int` value, the new line character will remain.  So the next call to `nextLine` will return an empty `String`, because there's no other characters proceeding the new line character, but will "wait" for input at the second `nextLine`, as no new data exists yet

items.title: Scanner is giving me trouble in Java
items.body:
I am writing a code to calculate the amount of crates you need depending on the amount of bottles you have.

6 bottles equal 1 crate.

For example, if you'd input 4 bottles, the output would be 1 crate. If you'd input 9 bottles, you'd get 2 crates etc..

Now I am facing some trouble trying to give the user a choice if they want to calculate again or not. Heres my code:

import java.util.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);

    boolean again = true;
    boolean loop = true;

    while (again) {
      System.out.println("CRATE CALCULATION");
      System.out.println("==================");
      System.out.println("Number of bottles?: ");

      int bottles;
      if (scanner.hasNextInt()) {
        bottles = scanner.nextInt();
        if (bottles <= 0) {
          System.out.println("You dont need any crates!");
        } else {
          int crates = (bottles + 5) / 6;
          System.out.println("You need " + crates + " crates!");
        }

        System.out.println("Do you want to calculate again? (y/n)");
        String choice = scanner.nextLine();
        scanner.nextLine();

        switch (choice) {
        case "y":
          again = true;
          break;
        case "n":
          again = false;
          break;
        default:
          System.out.println("Invalid choice. Lets try again.");
          again = true;
          break;
        }
      } else {
        System.out.println("You need to tell us the amount of bottles you have in numbers.");
        scanner.next();
      }
    }
  }
}

The problem I have is that whenever i enter "y" to calculate again, instead of running the "y" case, it runs the default one. I did research, even talked to ChatGPT but nothing works. Im thinking the problem here lies within scanner, but thats just me.

Help would be much appreciated.

comments.body_markdown: If a GC causes the memory to go down, it's probably not an application issue. Try changing the GC settings (maybe so it is doing collections earlier or that you have a bigger region size for the young generation). My guess is that you just have a lot of objects in the old generation.
comments.body: If a GC causes the memory to go down, it's probably not an application issue. Try changing the GC settings (maybe so it is doing collections earlier or that you have a bigger region size for the young generation). My guess is that you just have a lot of objects in the old generation.

comments.body_markdown: If the heap size gradually reaches 6G, and then falls without triggering a GC overhead limit exceeded exception, then I'd say everything is okay. Do you have a symptom (e.g. some requests take much longer than expected) which makes you think something is wrong?
comments.body: If the heap size gradually reaches 6G, and then falls without triggering a GC overhead limit exceeded exception, then I'd say everything is okay. Do you have a symptom (e.g. some requests take much longer than expected) which makes you think something is wrong?

comments.body_markdown: jvm can do that automatically when [there's memory error](https://www.baeldung.com/java-heap-dump-capture#automatically)
comments.body: jvm can do that automatically when there's memory error

comments.body_markdown: This sounds entirely, 100% normal for a JVM application.  It is normal for it to consume all the memory it is given access to, to perform a garbage collection when that threshold is reached, and for that number to go down.  If you want it to consume less memory, cap the heap size lower.
comments.body: This sounds entirely, 100% normal for a JVM application.  It is normal for it to consume all the memory it is given access to, to perform a garbage collection when that threshold is reached, and for that number to go down.  If you want it to consume less memory, cap the heap size lower.

comments.body_markdown: According to https://stackoverflow.com/a/51448003/139985, you can use `jcmd` (without the `:live` option) to get a heap dump without running the GC first.  Try running `jcmd` in a shell on the remote machine if you can't figure out how to make VisualVM do it.

items.body_markdown:
I am using VisualVM to extract a Heap Dump from a tomcat that is consuming a lot of memory resources. It starts consuming around 1GB but gradually reaches 5-6GB. It has peaks where the CPU is at 100% and where the memory is close to 99%.

I am trying to investigate this event by extracting heap dump, but every time I run a Heap Dump with the VisualVM software it runs a full Garbage Collection first which causes the heap memory to go from 5-6GB at the time of the request to around 1GB, and the heap dump extract that it extracts is 1GB, when I want it to extract the extract from the moment before the GC

Reading this thread https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1268336/how-can-i-take-a-heap-dump-on-java-5-without-garbage-collecting-first I have seen that I should use the value of "live" to false to prevent this from happening, but I can't find how to do it in VisualVM. I am connecting to the server using an SSH connection and tunneling, so the remote server does not have JDK installed.

How can I extract the entire heap dump remotely? Any advice to deal with this memory consumption? I am investigating the code in case there could be an error that causes consumption, but the fact that when a full GC is run the memory is restored to normal levels makes me suspicious.

comments.body_markdown: `person.firstName = p.firstName` is an *assignment*; it changes the variable `person.firstName` to point to the same string as `p.firstName`. I leave as an exercise for you to find out what `Boolean.parseBoolean(…)` is really for and why it isn’t appropriate here. As a general advice: don’t insert code into your program whose purpose you don’t understand.

comments.body_markdown: Step 1: count the occurrences of names in the second list (into a mutable map): `Map<String,Integer> counts = people2.stream() .collect(Collectors.toMap(Person::getFirstName, p -> 1, Integer::sum, HashMap::new));` Step 2: remove each person from the first list if their count is still not negative after decrementing: `people1.removeIf(p -> counts.merge(p.getFirstName(), -1, Integer::sum) >= 0);` That’s it. This example assumes that you have a method like `public String getFirstName() { return firstName; }` in your `Person` class as the `firstName` field is `private`.

comments.body_markdown: @StephenC OK, but only references to already created objects are held in the map, (plus entries, but they too have a tiny footprint) so O(tiny N) space

comments.body_markdown: The footprint of a `Map.Entry` is significantly more than a reference.  It is 3 references + an `int` + an object header.  (For a 64 bit JVM without compressed OOPS, it is 40 bytes per entry, I think.)  And then there is the `HashMap`'s hash array whose size is proportional to the number of entries (until N gets too large).  And the `ArrayList<Person>` value objects which comprise a Java object with a private primitive array.  It could add up to O(*significant* N) ... depending on your assumptions.

And the ArrayList<Person> value objects which comprise a Java object with a private primitive array. It could add up to O(significant N) ... depending on your assumptions.

comments.body_markdown: Since the OP’s code is not even remotely correct, it’s pointless to discuss its “main efficiency problem”. Then, the code is unnecessarily complicated, `map.getOrDefault(p.getFirstName(), null)` is not better than `map.get(p.getFirstName())` which will return `null` for absent keys anyway. Further, when the complexity is O(n * k) and you don’t know anything about the number of people with the same name (k), then it’s still O(n²), as O() denotes the *worst case*. Which could easily avoided by grouping into `ArrayDeque` instead of `ArrayList`, then, removing the first item is O(1).

answers.title: Return the difference between two lists by comparing key values, and not the entire objects in Java
answers.body:
The main efficiency problem you have is 2 nested loops, resulting in O(n2) time complexity.

However, you can do it O(n) time complexity by using a more efficient way to find the matching person from people1 to remove.

Map<String, Deque<Person>> map = people1.stream().collect(groupingBy(Person::getFirstName, toCollection(ArrayDeque::new)));

for (Person p : people2) {
    Optional.ofNullable(map.get(p.getFirstName()))
      .filter(list -> !list.isEmpty())
      .ifPresent(Deque::remove);
}

people1 = map.values().stream().flatMap(Deque::stream).toList();

This creates a map (actually as HashMap, which has constant time efficiency) to find the list of people with the same first name. The lists are LinkedList, which has O(1) time complexity for removing the first element.

Then, for each person in list 2, the list of people with the same first name is retrieved from the map and if it exists and is not empty, the first person is removed from it.

At the end of the loop, list 1 is constructed from whatever people remain in the map.

This algorithm scales linearly (both time and space).

answers.title: Return the difference between two lists by comparing key values, and not the entire objects in Java
answers.body:
"... I want to iterate through the people2 list, and if a person with the same name exists in the people1 list, then find the first match and remove it (only caring about name, not age). ..."

Use an Iterator to traverse each list.

Iterator<Person> x = people1.iterator();
Iterator<Person> y = people2.iterator();
String s;
while (x.hasNext()) {
    s = x.next().getFirstName();
    while (y.hasNext()) {
        if (y.next().getFirstName().equals(s)) {
            x.remove();
            y.remove();
            break;
        }
    }
}

Or, if you're utilizing Stream#filter, use a while-loop for the people2 list, so you can remove the value.

people1 =
    people1.stream().filter(x -> {
        Iterator<Person> i = people2.iterator();
        String s = x.getFirstName();
        while (i.hasNext()) {
            if (i.next().getFirstName().equals(s)) {
                i.remove();
                return false;
            }
        }
        return true;
    }).toList();

Output

[John 61, John 13]

items.title: Return the difference between two lists by comparing key values, and not the entire objects in Java
items.body:
I have two lists from the same class (e.g. a Person class with a name and age property), and I am trying to come up with an efficient way to remove elements from List A, if they appear in List B, but only if the name property matches (ignoring age). I don't want to remove ALL values that have a matching name from List B, but rather remove one value from List A for every matching name in List B.

Here's an example:

public class Person {
    private String firstName;
    private Integer age;

    public Person(String firstName, Integer age) {
        this.firstName = firstName;
        this.age = age;
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {

        Person p1 = new Person("John", 25);
        Person p2 = new Person("Lisa", 54);
        Person p3 = new Person("Mike", 61);
        Person p4 = new Person("John", 61);
        Person p5 = new Person("John", 13);
        List<Person> people1 = new ArrayList<Person>();
        people1.add(p1);
        people1.add(p2);
        people1.add(p3);
        people1.add(p4);
        people1.add(p5);

        Person p6 = new Person("John", 88);
        Person p7 = new Person("Lisa", 66);
        Person p8 = new Person("Mike", 71);
        List<Person> people2 = new ArrayList<Person>();
        people2.add(p6);
        people2.add(p7);
        people2.add(p8);


        for (Person p : people2) {
            people1.stream()
                .filter(person -> Boolean.parseBoolean(person.firstName = p.firstName))
                .findFirst()
                .ifPresent(person -> people1.remove(person));
        } // This is what i've tried, but it doesn't work and seems very inefficient

        System.out.println(people1);
    }

Basically, I want to iterate through the people2 list, and if a person with the same name exists in the people1 list, then find the first match and remove it (only caring about name, not age).

Desired Result: A list containing

  • John, 61
  • John, 13
